Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Development Of Ritual And Social Solidarity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Charles Stanish and Mr. Benjamin Nigra of the University of California, Los Angeles, along with Peruvian colleagues, will investigate the role of scheduled political events in the emergence of early complex societies. Prior research suggests that intensified interaction between independent communities is key to the establishment of early political hierarchies and regional economic cooperation. Scheduled economic events, mediated through ritual in which disparate communities gather together at regular intervals at recognized locations, serve as public forums in which strangers exchange, communicate norms, build novel economic relationships, and vie for social status. As small communities become unified into regional polities, ceremonial events often lose their public character and become restricted to specific social classes such as elites or specialists. This investigation asks: under what material and social conditions do ritual events become exclusive? Why do some events remain open to the general public while participation in others becomes strictly guarded? What are the regional economic impacts of massive public gatherings, and how do these impacts change with emerging social inequality? Archaeology is uniquely suited to address this question by accessing long-term data on the pre-modern economics and long-term social processes. "Ritualized' economic events are not restricted to the ancient world, but remain ever present in the modern day United States. These events, all highly ritualized and involving representatives from independent (and often competing) groups, have notable economic and political consequences for how segments of modern society form larger cooperative communities.

Stanish and Nigra will examine the specific modes of economic investment that independent communities made in the construction, upkeep and participation in massive, monumental ceremonial structures among the Paracas peoples of the Peruvian south coast (800 BCE - 200 CE). They will focus on several sites in the Chincha Valley, where cooperative labor between independent Paracas communities was used to construct at least a dozen platform structures containing deep sunken courts. The researchers will radiocarbon date non-local offerings recovered from one of these monuments, Huaca Soto, to determine when it was constructed, for how long it was used for ceremonial purposes, and the date of its eventual decommissioning. By combining these dates with stratigraphic excavations focused on the depositions of long-distance trade goods as ritual offerings, architectural renovations over time that restricted public access, and the establishment of early urban communities around the base of the structure, they will reconstruct the early economic networks and intercommunity dynamics that led to the establishment of strong political hierarchies and social inequality by the beginning of first millennium CE. All aspects of the proposed research will be conducted as part of field training for American undergraduates and will expose students to field excavation, survey, specialist data analyses, and conservation of archaeological sites and remains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For most of our history, human beings have lived in small, mobile communities in which most members were closely related. These communities were characterized by low levels of socioeconomic inequality, fluid leadership, and limited occupational specialization. Today, almost all human beings live in modern states – societies composed of thousands of individuals characterized by a strong division of labor, strict hierarchical bureaucracy, and differentiated access to wealth. This series of changes occurred independently in multiple world regions over the past 10,000 years, and is referred to by anthropologists as the evolution of political complexity. One of the chief objectives of scientific archaeology is to determine the conditions that facilitated this transition.

This process is driven by economic needs in world of scarce resources. Groups that can guarantee fair contributions from members typically outcompete fractious communities beset by free-riding. Recent research suggests that regular interaction between community members promotes this kind of pro-social cooperation. Early religious ritual played a key role in this process. Public ceremonies bring individuals together who otherwise may interact rarely or not at all. These events allow individuals to negotiate new partnerships, enable leaders to publicly communicate the fairness ‘norms’ that support cooperative behavior, and for communities to redistribute surplus production. It is no surprise that ritual structures are typically the earliest form of non-domestic architecture to appear in archaeological cultures around the world.  

Our research explores the co-evolution of ritual architecture and political complexity among the Paracas peoples of Peru’s southern coast (ca. 800 BCE – 200 CE). Paracas is well-known for its polychromatic textiles and ceramics, which represent some of the most advanced artisanry in the pre-Columbian Americas. Paracas communities underwent the shift from a cluster of independent groups to a regional-scale complex society in the final centuries BCE. Not unsurprisingly, Paracas peoples in the Chincha Valley also built the first monumental structures in the region – massive ritualized platform mounds containing deep sunken courts. We hypothesized that intensified ritual activity at these sites was an important factor in the emergence of Paracas political complexity.

Between 2012-2016 our research group conducted a series of excavations in several Paracas ritual structures. Our objective was to better understand how this architecture was built and used, to test for the presence of non-local goods that might indicate widening economic networks, to search for evidence for emerging ritual specialists, and to gauge the political and economic relationship between ritual structures located in different parts of the valley.

One of these structures, Huaca Soto, is the subject of this study. Huaca Soto is approximately the size of a modern football field, contains three sunken courts, and rises more than 15 meters above the local floodplain. After excavating two of the courts, we were able to confirm that the structure was used for formal ceremonial processions. It was painstakingly maintained throughout its early history, underwent multiple renovation episodes, and hosted major events involving sizable groups of Paracas people.

We were awarded NSF funding to facilitate radiocarbon dating of this structure. These dates provided a crucial timeline for understanding the site’s long term evolution and its chronological relationship to other Paracas ritual courts in the Chincha Valley. We submitted 30 radiocarbon samples to the W. M. Keck Carbon Cycle Accelerator Mass Spectrometry Laboratory (University of California, Irvine) covering Huaca Soto’s deepest to most recent remains. This allowed us to trace the structure’s development from its earliest appearance until its abandonment by Paracas peoples.

Results indicate that Huaca Soto was reconstructed at least four times between the 8th and 5th centuries BCE, making it the oldest scientifically dated site in the valley and one of the oldest known examples of Paracas ritual architecture in the region. This suggests that Chincha was a core area of Paracas development beginning quite early. As time passed, the site steadily increased in size (and thus the labor required to build and maintain it), paralleling the emergence of political complexity across the south coast. It is also clear that Huaca Soto was significantly older than other Paracas platform mounds in Chincha for which we have excavation data, suggesting that these ‘spin-offs’ or ‘satellite centers’ emerged later as Chincha communities grew larger and more diverse. In short, ritual architecture and practice at Huaca Soto became a paradigm to be followed by Paracas communities as they expanded across the valley and began to form regional-scale economic relationships.

As part of our field research we trained dozens of American and Peruvian undergraduates through an accredited field school program. Students learned basic field methods, including excavation techniques, recovery and handling of radiocarbon samples, and a battery of scientific analyses essential to field archaeology. We also engaged with local community groups and individuals directly in our research. The result was a diverse international project that furthered the scientific objectives of modern archaeology.
